import scipy.stats as stats

source.1d488664:
### What's next?

One flaw my analysis may have is that the games played inside of the Bubble are mostly playoff games or games that are more intense. Thus the stats of the players in the Bubble may be slightly higher than usual. So next, I will collect data from past playoffs and compare the playoff played in the Bubble and see if there is any differences. 

As for Paul George, although his performance was consistent in the season of 2019-20, the criticism he recieved may be an result of a worse performance than the previous season. And what caused him to perform worse in the 2019-20 season? Roaster changes? Rr different playstyles? That's what I am gonna explore next.

source.d2f3d93a:
PG13 is one of the best forwards in the NBA right now. And in the previous season, 2018-19 season, he was one of the MVP candidates. However, in the 2019-20 season, especially in the Bubble, PG received a large amount of criticisms for under performing in the most important games and was given the name "Pandemic P". What happened to him? Did he really under performed?

I pulled his data from the 2019-20 season, which is a total of 42 games played outside of the Bubble and 19 games played inside of the Bubble. And here is what I found.
source.9f062243: The t-test gave us a p-value of 0.60 which is way higher than the alpha value of 0.05. It indicates that there is no significant difference between PG's FGM inside and outside of the Bubble.
source.0e8190fd: #### We get a p-value of 0.49 which is way higher than the alpha-value of 0.05 which indicates that there is no significant difference between the Rebounds per game in the Bubble or outside of the Bubble
source.cbba16ee:
# Analysis of the NBA Bubble Season

After the outbreak of the COVID-19, and after two NBA All-Stars, Rudy Gobert and Donovan Mitchell, were tested positive for COVID-19 in March, NBA has to suspend all its games to protect its players. 4 months later, NBA restarted in the "Bubble", an isolated zone at Walt Disney World near Orlando without any audiences. 

Resting for 4 months and playing in an isolated environment without cheering crowds, people questioned that whether the players could perform at a level they do regularly, especially when the season approached its end, the most competitive period as teams competing for a position in the playoff. 

This notebook explores how the players perform in the Bubble.

![](https://theundefeated.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bucks-e1598474176785.jpg?w=1024)
source.e06d145c: ## Comparison of Inside and Outside of the Bubble
source.a17d8a87: #### We get a p-value of 0.66 which is way higher than the alpha-value of 0.05 which indicates that there is no significant difference between the Assist per game in the Bubble or outside of the Bubble
source.4ad72f8e:
Then combine the Bubble regular season data with the Bubble playoff season data:

Notice that all the records are calculated per game, and players play different number games under this two different time periods, so to combine the data of these two periods, we need to(use average points as an example):
* Calculate the total points scores during the Bubble regular season("PTS" * "GP")
* Calculate the total points scored during the Bubble playoff season("PTS" * "GP")
* Add them up and divided by the total nunmber of games played
source.993bf316: #### We get a p-value of 0.91 which is way higher than the alpha-value of 0.05 which indicates that there is no significant difference between the Three-Pointer Percentage per game in the Bubble or outside of the Bubble
source.fc7b3d71: #### We get a p-value of 0.21 which is way higher than the alpha-value of 0.05 which indicates that there is no significant difference between the PTS per game in the Bubble or outside of the Bubble
source.6b28c729: The t-test gave us a p-value of 0.84 which is way higher than the alpha value of 0.05. It indicates that there is no significant difference between PG's FG% inside and outside of the Bubble.
source.2c039819: Based on the graphs of distributions, each stats have a similar pattern inside and outside of the Bubble. And the statistical tests all indicate that there is no significant difference between the players' performance inside and outside of the Bubble. Some discrepancies between the two curves like in the graph of FT% per game, the distribution inside the Bubble has a much higher variance than the distribution outside of the Bubble has. This may be a result of more games are played outside of the Bubble and it has a larger sample size when calculating the average FT% which may be closer to the "actual" FT% of the players.
